SCCPSS welcomes Derrick Campbell as Johnson High's new head coach for boys' basketball! Mr. Derrick “Chuck” Campbell is a native of Harlem, New York who graduated from Savannah State University with a Bachelors of Arts in Mass Communications in 2000.

After college, he developed a passion for training athletes. This passion eventually led to recognition as one of Savannah’s top basketball trainers. He began his coaching career as an assistant coach at H.V. Jenkins High School with Bakari Bryant and would later continue his coaching duties at Sol C. Johnson High School under the leadership of Utaff Gordon. During his seven years of coaching, Mr. Campbell helped his teams advance to three Region Championships, three State Final Fours, and two State Championship appearances.

Mr. Campbell’s coaching philosophy is simple, “Success depends less on strength of body than upon strength of mind and character.” -Arnold Palmer

post_text: We held a press conference this morning to make sure everyone is clear on our position: Next week is spring break. Students and staff are out of school. We are taking this time to do a deep clean of our facilities and will continue to monitor the situation as it pertains to the coronavirus. At this time, we expect to welcome our school families back to the classroom on March 23. We realize that things can change at any time, which is why our Task Force will continue to meet regularly to access new information as it becomes available. Our close partnership with the Department of Public Health informs and shapes our response to any change in the situation. Should our plan of action change, we will use every communications tool in our power to let our families know of our intentions. We want our students and families to enjoy Spring Break! We urge you to continue being vigilant about washing your hands and maintaining good hygiene habits while away from school.

Parents and staff are encouraged to monitor the weather forecast closely and stay alert to changing conditions.

post_text: SCCPSS students were treated to a special presentation from Mountainfilm on Tour Savannah January 22 - 24. Over 1800 students attended a special program of documentary short films, which included the film RAW Tuba, the story of Dr. Richard Antoine White and his brother, William Smith. Dr. White grew up on the streets of Baltimore, and went on to become a world-class symphony musician, professor and the first African American in the world to receive a Doctorate in Music for Tuba Performance Dr. White and Mr. Smith were on hand for a Q&A session with the students. #Mountainfilm2020 #mountainfilmtour #publicschooladvantage
